Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Blockchain-Based Web of Trust for Edge Computing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact of this I-Corps project is in enabling more comprehensive, secure, private, and real-time analysis of internet of things (IoT) data generated by connected devices such as mobile phones and connected vehicles. Vast amounts of IoT data are generated each year. Even the most useful IoT data is often transferred through and stored in systems that can have privacy and security problems. This I-Corps project has the potential to refactor how existing IoT workloads work in a secure fashion, enabling the processing of this data to be secured and anonymized directly in the networks in which they are generated. From a commercial standpoint, this technology can refactor how existing corporations deploy analytics to utilize IoT data. Much like cloud infrastructure refactored how large digital workloads were handled into specialized computing centers, this technology can refactor deployment of large-scale, real-time data analytics onto the networks of devices generating them. Ultimately, this means corporations will have access to data processing capabilities that can scale to how fast they generate data, and consumers will benefit from privacy and data security guarantees.

This I-Corps project is based on two novel technological developments surrounding blockchain and decentralized systems. The first is a context aware reputation system for digital devices that acts as a peer-to-peer credit system for machines. The second is a way of routing and storing data such that it is impossible to recover any information from a single compromised machine. These two innovations are inspired by the original idea of decentralization as taken from the internet, with the reputation system motivated by Pretty Good Privacy (PGP) and the routing/storage mechanism inspired by Named Data Networking and polynomial-based cryptographic techniques. This inspiration is applied and mixed with current understanding of blockchain systems to create a more secure yet still highly scalable peer to peer network. Ultimately, these two systems working together can vastly scale data storage transactions per data shard as contrasted with existing blockchain systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our I-Corps team was comprised of Yiqi Hou (EL), Yongqi Gan (TL), and Yoon Choi (IM). We were interested in seeing the commercial viability of an IoT edge security technology created to better secure sensitive information on IoT devices and allow them to process this sensitive information. Over the 7 weeks of the initial course, the team interviewed 100 people in the mobility manufacturing IoT ecosystem. These people were hypothesized to be critical players in the value chain and commercialization of our software technology, and we spent the 7 weeks attempting to explore the ecosystem and understand how each key player’s value system worked.

The goal of this program was to explore the possibility of monetizing the secure edge processing technology. We initially looked towards the automotive and mobility industry, as we thought there would be a serious need for efficient edge processing in vehicles. In the process, we spoke with Directors/VPs of Infrastructure and many of these automotive companies and realized there could be a bigger need on the manufacturing side. We spent most of the 7 weeks digging into the automotive manufacturing industry, but ultimately realized that there wasn’t a strong enough signal, and that the real problems couldn’t be solved by our technology.

During the program, however, we realized the fintech industry was interested in our technology. Due to the massive amounts of consumer data that theoretically could be utilized, there was value for our technology, especially because privacy regulations and other technical limitations prevented their use currently. The majority of the post-National NSF program exploration was around this point.

Post-National program, the team interviewed over 50 more key customers, particularly on the digital security and innovation side, before realizing that the business model looked a lot like a consultancy. After speaking with some Finance ministers at the Singapore Fintech Festival, we realized that firms such as Accenture were applying a similar consultancy model using blockchain technology in fintech.

Prior to the NSF I-Corps program, EL and team members had been working on this as research adjacent to research they were doing at UC Berkeley’s Deep Drive research lab. At the end of the I-Corps program, TL transitioned away from the project to focus on other opportunities, and is currently working at Google on low-latency consumer applications. EL transitioned away from the project as a company, as the resulting business model from the program looked more like a services-based model (like a consultancy/contractor). He is currently working with both an automotive consortium as well as a blockchain company as a consultant, continuing to explore the viability of a consultancy-based approach to the software expertise in secure IoT edge processing. Full-time, EL is working under the former COO of Y Combinator on a startup venture in the mobility industry.

The experience of the National NSF I-Corps program has helped inform the decision to move forward on a smaller scale, as most consultancies do not have the same recurring revenue model that many big corporations do, and that modern technology firms need to exhibit to receive investments. We thank the NSF for funding our efforts, and also Rhonda Shrader and Eugene Noh for their unwavering support and continued positivity during our endeavors!
